Seven Signs Your Small Business Needs a New Website

Having a strong web presence is a fundamental part of running an effective small business. But it’s not enough just to be able to say you have a website. You need a site that works for you. It needs to be current and it needs to help you drive sales.

Here are seven ways to know that it’s time to refresh your existing small business website:

1. It’s Not Responsive (Mobile Friendly)

Did you know that an estimated 207.2 million Americans access the web via a smartphone or mobile device? If your site isn’t responsive (meaning it doesn’t have the ability to work on any mobile device or tablet) you’re undoubtedly losing customers.

Not only does a non-responsive website frustrate potential customers and contribute to a negative user impression, it also affects the way that results come back for online searches. (Read: Google does its best to avoid showing non-mobile results to smartphone and tablet users.)

2. It’s Old (by Web Standards)

If it’s been more than five years since your last refresh, your design likely looks out of date. An unattractive website that’s hard for the user to navigate isn’t helping your sales, and could have a negative effect on your brand identity and perceived professionalism.

3. It’s Not Social

Your website doesn’t link to your social media accounts. Having a social presence online is crucial, especially for small businesses looking to spread the word. Social media is a great way to build relationships and keep in touch with your customers, as well as an easy way for you and your customers to promote your business. In short: an unsociable site is a missed opportunity.

4. Your Bounce Rate is High

Bounce rate measures the percentage of users who come to your website and leave without interacting (so they’re only viewing the page they arrived on). You can find this metric on your site’s Google Analytics dashboard, and it’s a pretty strong signal that the visitor didn’t find what they were looking for, became overwhelmed with information, or didn’t get a great first impression. For most core pages (especially your hompeage) you should aim for a bounce rate of less than 50%. 

5. It Uses Flash

While Flash was a great multimedia tool back in the day, smartphones, tablets, and even some browsers don’t support Flash. Further, Flash content is not indexable by search engines (which makes being found online even tougher), can be a security risk, and slows down page speeds (which is especially bad when you have impatient customers). Speaking of page speed…

6. Your Web Pages Load Slowly

Nearly half of all visitors will leave a website that does not load in three seconds. For every second your site doesn’t load, you lose a portion of your audience to the impatient internet archives. Slow load times can be attributed to a number of factors, from too-large images to sloppy code or overworked hosting. But whatever the cause, a slow website isn’t just a nuisance, it can also it can be financially costly.

7. You Can’t Update Content

The inability to control what’s on your site makes it impossible to stay current and provide your users with the most up-to-date information about your company. That is, unless you’re paying someone to actively do it for you. The lack of current information will not only make your site look dated, it can also hurt your business by robbing you of the ability to promote new products and services or implement seasonal promotions.

Enlisting the help of a good content management system when you redesign your site puts the power back into your hands. Using a CMS like WordPress, for instance, will allow you to make updates to your site, whenever you need to.

Does your website fall under any of the categories above? If so, it’s time to consider a new website and the value it can bring to your business.
